prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: While there is sparse case law, actions have been brought due to alleged systematic targeting to induce employees to leave their employment.

In Dylex Ltd. v. Factory Carpet Corporation,[1] the court refused a motion to restrain the defendant from soliciting the plaintiff's employees. See also E.M. Plastic and Electric Products Ltd. v. Hobza,[2] which discussed the enticement of employees to leave employment.[3] See also, section 4:9.
Dylex Ltd. v. Factory Carpet Corporation (1989), 44 C.P.C. (2d) 96 (Ont. H.C.J.).
E.M. Plastic and Electric Products Ltd. v. Hobza (1992), 43 C.P.R. (3d) 74 (Ont. (Gen. Div.)), supp. reasons 43 C.P.R. (3d) 74 at p. 128 (Ont. Ct. (Gen. Div.)), vard 52 C.P.R. (3d) 166 (C.A.).

Recruitment lawsuits are starting to become more common. For example, in February 2001, Compaq Computers filed a lawsuit against RLX Technologies in Texas alleging that confidential information was used to recruit employees. See also the decision in ADGA Systems International Ltd. v. Valcom Ltd. (1999), 168 D.L.R. (4th) 351, 43 O.R. (3d) 101 (C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 183 D.L.R. (4th) vi, 134 O.A.C. 400n.
